title.rendered: Marketing Strategy for Food Delivery Business: 12 Proven Tips to Boost Growth

content.rendered:
Let’s talk about the elephant in the room: A large majority, 90%, of restaurants, hotels, and bars use social media for promotions. 

That’s nearly everyone in the industry, and yet, many still struggle to see results. 

Why?

The truth is, most of them scatter their efforts across platforms without a clear vision and marketing strategy for food delivery business. They post randomly, run ads without tracking results, and wonder why their ROI stays low.

But to promote your food delivery business you need – 

The right message. The right channel. At the right time.

If you’re not sure how to figure that out, you’ve come to the right place. 

In this blog, I’ll show you what a smart marketing strategy for a food delivery business actually looks like and how to build one that drives real results.

Key Takeaways

Before we go further, here’s what you’ll learn:

✅Benefits of having marketing strategies for your food delivery business 

✅12 effective strategies to drive growth for your business 

✅Avoidable mistakes that you should look for 

✅One powerful solution that improves your marketing strategies 

How Can a Food Delivery Business Get More Customers?

Let’s take a high-level view of the process before breaking it into actionable parts.

To get more customers for your food delivery business, you should start with the basics: know who you’re trying to reach. It can be busy parents, office workers, students, late-night snackers, etc. Each group has different habits, so your messaging should match their needs.

Then, make it easy to find and trust you. This means:

  • A clear online presence (Google, Maps, website).
  • Strong social media profiles with good photos and reviews.
  • Simple, fast ordering with no sign-up hurdles.

Next, focus on offers that make people act. Think first-time discounts, free delivery, or meal combos that feel like a deal.

Here are some additional ways: 

  • Partner with local influencers for shoutouts.
  • Run geo-targeted ads so your offer hits the right people.
  • Use a loyalty program to bring customers back.

So you see, it all starts with who you’re marketing to. You need to find out first who your customers are. Let’s have a brief overview of that concept: 

Who Are Your Customers and What Do They Want?

Not everyone likes the same food or service. Some people care about fast delivery. Others want healthy meals or budget-friendly options.

To figure this out:

  • Ask for feedback after orders.
  • Study reviews and ratings.
  • Watch which menu items sell the most.

For example, if most of your customers are students, focus on affordable meals and late-night delivery. If your audience is busy professionals, highlight quick and easy ordering options.

Each group wants different things, so your marketing strategy for food delivery business should speak to all of them in different ways.

Pro tip: Know their habits, and you’ll know how to reach them.

Next, we’ll break down each step, share actionable advice about food delivery promotion ideas, and help you design a plan that fits your goals. If you’re ready to take your food delivery business to the next level, keep reading.

What is an Online Food Delivery Marketing Strategy?

An online food delivery marketing strategy is a plan to promote your business and attract customers through digital channels. It includes everything from social media posts to email campaigns, loyalty programs, and even partnerships with food apps.

Think of it as your roadmap to success. Without a strategy, your efforts might feel scattered, and you could miss opportunities to grow your business.

What are the Benefits of Having a Marketing Strategy for an Online Food Delivery Business?

So, why should you bother creating a marketing strategy? Let’s break it down below – 

Attract More Customers

Think about it: how will people find your business if you don’t promote it? 

A good strategy helps you reach new customers who haven’t heard of you yet. For example, running ads on Facebook or Instagram can introduce your food to thousands of potential buyers.

Build a Loyal Customer Base

When your message is clear and your service is consistent, people come back. A good strategy helps you create repeat business. 

Helps You Stand Out

Let’s be honest – there are tons of food delivery options out there. A sharp digital marketing plan helps you show why you’re different. Maybe it’s your faster delivery, better pricing, or unique dishes. The right message helps you own that difference.

Saves Time and Money

Without a plan, you might waste money on things that don’t work, like random ads or promotions that flop. A strategy helps you focus on what actually brings results. 

You can save time and money by focusing your efforts on what works, and you can be sure that every dollar you spend improves your overall objectives.

Data-Driven Decisions

You’ll know what works and what doesn’t, so you can spend money on marketing that actually brings results. This realization helps you allocate your money sensibly, focusing on channels and strategies that produce actual results. 

Investing in marketing strategies that increase involvement, sales, and finally, business growth will help you avoid wasting resources on guesswork. Less wasted money and more relevant actions that appeal to your audience follow from this.

12 Powerful Marketing Strategies for a Food Delivery Business

Now that we understand the foundation, let’s dive into the real work. These proven strategies will transform your food delivery business from invisible to irresistible. 

Rank Higher with Local SEO and Google Business Profile

Before running ads or jumping onto every social platform, food delivery businesses should start with something more foundational local visibility.

For this step, first think from your customers’ perspectives while searching. Let me show you a few examples: 

“Late-night pizza delivery near me”

“Best burgers in New York”

“Halal food delivery Bologna ”

These are intent-driven searches, and if your restaurant or delivery brand isn’t showing up here, you’re missing customers who are actively looking to order. It’s one of the greatest local restaurant marketing tactics. 

So you should start by claiming and optimizing your Google Business Profile. It’s free, and it’s often the first thing people see when they search for food delivery in your area. Once your profile is live and optimized, you can go into more advanced settings of Local SEO. 

For example: 

Maneki Ramen is a Japanese restaurant in Worcester, UK used a local SEO strategy to target keywords like “Japanese food near me.” They improved their Google Business Profile and website to help people find them. As a result, they had over 3,000 profile interactions in one month. This was a 40.4% increase from the previous year. They also saw a big rise in calls and website visits, which led to more bookings.

Best Practices Checklist:

✅ Google Business Profile fully updated (every 30–60 days)

✅ Delivery keywords added to website pages and metadata

✅ Menu structured with SEO-friendly URLs

✅ Use schema markup for location and delivery info

✅ Encourage keyword-rich Google reviews from regulars

Extra Tip:

Use tools like Moz Local or BrightLocal to check your listings in directories. These tools help find problems, like missing addresses, old phone numbers, or unclaimed citations that can hurt your rankings.

Run Targeted Ads on Facebook and Instagram

Social media ads can be a goldmine for food delivery businesses if used correctly. While many throw money at random ads in the name of social media strategy for food delivery, the most successful brands use highly targeted campaigns designed to speak directly to their ideal customer.

Start by identifying your customer segment. Ask these questions to yourself- 

Are you targeting young professionals in the city? 

Health-conscious students? 

Late-night snackers?

After that, you should –

✅Set up your ad manager account ( if you do not have one already ) 

✅Create a new campaign

✅Define Audience

✅Set budget and schedule 

✅Choose Ad placement

✅Create Ad 

✅Monitor and Analysis 

Now let’s have a look at a real-world scenario: 

When Foodpanda wanted to improve its customer acquisition efficiency, it ran A/B tests on Facebook using Meta Advantage+ catalogue ads. This approach resulted in a 9% lower cost per first order, proving the effectiveness of data-driven ad optimization.

Extra Tip:

Always A/B test different versions, and track metrics like click-through rates and return on ad spend (ROAS). That’s how you turn ad dollars into repeat customers.

Partner with Local Restaurants

If you operate a multi-restaurant food delivery platform, forming strategic partnerships with local eateries is more than a business model; it’s a marketing opportunity.

Here’s how it works:

  • Promote your restaurant partners through co-branded campaigns
  • Highlight them in email newsletters or social media shoutouts
  • Offer joint deals that benefit both brands (e.g., “Order from SushiKing and get 10% off your next pizza from Bella Italia”)

This type of cross-promotion helps both sides grow. For the platform, it builds credibility by aligning with popular or trusted local names. For the restaurant, it brings new orders without needing extra tech or delivery resources.

Send Push Notifications and SMS at the Right Time

Push notifications and SMS can be a powerful tool. But you need to be careful and precise. Used poorly, they become annoying. But used strategically, they drive immediate action.

The key is timing and relevance.

Don’t blast users with daily messages. Instead, segment your audience. Here’s an example of what you can do: 

  • Send lunch reminders around 11:30 AM to office workers
  • Offer late-night deals to students and night owls
  • Send messages about personalized favorites or past orders


Extra Tip:

Use urgency. Messages like “Only 1 hour left!” create action. You can also include a clear CTA with a direct link to the ordering page.

Launch a Referral Program

Word-of-mouth is still one of the most powerful drivers of growth. Referral programs play a crucial role in this case. 

But for a referral program to work, it must offer real value on both ends. People trust recommendations from friends more than ads. A good referral system turns customers into marketers.

Example setup:

Add a “Refer a friend” button right inside your app. Let users copy a referral code, send it via WhatsApp, or post on social.

Extra Tip:

Make it visible. Promote referral programs on your homepage, order confirmation pages, and push messages.

Build Loyalty Programs for Delivery Services

Customer acquisition is expensive. Loyalty programs are a game-changer for keeping customers coming back. 

A great example is Uber Eats’ Eats Pass. For a small monthly fee, subscribers get free delivery and discounts on eligible orders, along with access to exclusive promotions. It’s simple, rewarding, and keeps people hooked.

Best Practices:

✅Offer points or perks for every purchase to encourage repeat business.

✅ Provide rewards like free delivery, discounts, or exclusive deals.

✅Celebrate milestones with messages like, “Congrats on your 10th order!”

Extra Tip:

Make your loyalty program feel personal by surprising customers with bonuses during holidays or on their birthdays. It’s these little touches that make people feel valued.

Work With Food Bloggers and Local Influencers

Influencers already have loyal followers who trust their recommendations. 

Why not tap into that?

Collaborating with local food influencers and bloggers can put your brand in front of thousands of hungry followers in a matter of hours.

But here’s the trick: don’t chase the biggest name while going for influencer marketing. Go local. Find micro-influencers (3k–30k followers) in your city who:

  • Actively post about takeout, delivery, or restaurant experiences
  • Have strong engagement (likes, comments, shares, and not just followers)
  • Have an audience that overlaps with your target customers

Take DoorDash’s Miami campaign, for example. They teamed up with local influencers to promote their service and share exclusive promo codes. The result? DoorDash’s Miami campaign brought in more than 8,500 new customers in just 20 days.

Best Practices: 

✅ Send a free meal in exchange for a reel, TikTok, or story

✅ Provide a promo code that they can offer to their followers

✅ Track each creator’s code to measure ROI

Extra Tip: 

Collaborate with micro-influencers. They often charge less but have highly engaged audiences.

Get Listed on Popular Review and Delivery Aggregator Sites

A big chunk of customers don’t search for your food delivery app or brand directly. They discover you through platforms they already trust.

That’s why listings and reviews on platforms like:

  • Google Business
  • Yelp
  • Zomato
  • TripAdvisor
  • Trustpilot
  • App stores (for delivery apps)

…can make or break first impressions.

Make sure you claim and optimize your profile:

  • Add high-quality food photos
  • Keep menus, delivery hours, and location details updated
  • Reply to reviews (good or bad) with professionalism

Example: Uber Eats took the approach to building trust by claiming their profile on Trustpilot, a platform where real users can share their honest opinions. To encourage feedback, they sent review invitations outside of Trustpilot’s systems, which are automatically labeled as “invited.” This strategy not only increased the number of reviews but also showcased authentic customer experiences (both good and bad).

Best Practices: 

✅ Encourage happy customers to leave a review with post-order follow-ups

✅ Use reviews as marketing assets. You can feature them in emails and social proof sections on your site

✅ Track ratings over time to identify common pain points and improve operations

Also Read: Breaking Down the Uber Eats Business Model

Create Engaging Content on Social Media

For food delivery businesses like Uber Eats, DoorDash, or Foodpanda, social media isn’t just a marketing tool; it’s a way to build trust, showcase variety, and drive orders. The key is to create content that appeals to both restaurants and customers while keeping the platform lively and engaging.

What to post:

  • Rider stories or behind-the-scenes delivery moments
  • Creator collabs with food bloggers, ordering from your app
  • Funny, relatable memes about late-night cravings or indecisive eaters
  • Top-ordered dishes in your city (and what it says about the people there)
  • Reels of new restaurant launches or limited-time menus
  • Polls that get users involved (“Which city orders more burgers?”)

Example: 

Uber Eats nailed this with their “Get almost, almost anything” campaign. They brought in a globally recognized actor and used humor-driven storytelling to show just how far their delivery range goes, without overpromising.

One of them was Tom Felton, known for playing a sneaky wizard. In the ad, he tries to order a magic wand but ends up causing chaos by accidentally making his neighbor disappear.

The campaign shows how Uber Eats isn’t just for food—you can order groceries, and more. It’s a clever way to highlight the app’s ability to deliver almost anything you need and capture the target market. 

Make Promotional Offers That Drive Action

Promotions are a simple yet powerful way to attract new customers and retain existing ones. Running a promotion is easy for many food business owners, but it’s the strategy that makes the difference. 

Best Practices:

✅Create urgency with time-bound offers like “Order in the next hour and save 20%.”

✅Bundle deals, such as “Buy one, get one free” or “Add a drink for $1 with any meal.”

✅Tailor promotions to specific audiences—students, families, or late-night snackers.

Remember, discounts should drive volume and retention, not just eat into margins.

Optimize App Store Listing for Your Food Delivery App

If your food delivery app isn’t optimized for app stores, you’re leaving thousands of potential users behind.

App Store Optimization (ASO) is like SEO (Search Engine Optimization), but for apps. It helps you rank higher in search results when users look for on-demand food delivery services near them. 

Your ASO checklist:

  • Keyword-rich app name & subtitle (e.g., “XYZ – Fast Food Delivery in Jeddah”)
  • Compelling screenshots with benefit-driven captions
  • High-converting app description 
  • Regular review responses to show engagement
  • Strong review & rating acquisition strategy

Better ASO means more installs or customer acquisition for food apps without spending a dime on ads.

For example, even the popular food delivery apps like Uber Eats, Doordash use ASO strategies to keep themselves relevant and competitive in this industry. 

Build a High-Performance Website That Converts

Even if your business is mobile-first, don’t underestimate the power of a high-converting website.

Your site is often the first stop for new customers (especially from Google). If it’s clear, engaging, and up-to-date, you’re already winning.

What your website should do:

  • Clearly explain how your delivery service works
  • Show real-time delivery zones or coverage
  • Feature top restaurants or trending meals
  • Include prominent app download CTAs
  • Load in under 3 seconds on mobile
  • A live chat feature for instant customer support.

Mistakes to Avoid When Marketing a Food Delivery Business

I hope you’ve listed down the strategies. Now it’s time to take note of the mistakes that many food delivery businesses have made and what you must avoid if you want results without wasting time and money.

  • Sending too many messages or notifications
  • Not checking what’s working through data
  • Trying to target everyone at once
  • Changing your brand look and voice too often
  • Running ads without testing different versions
  • Ignoring repeat customers and focusing only on new ones
  • Copying competitors without a clear plan
  • Having a slow or hard-to-use website or app
  • Offering discounts all the time with no profit plan
  • Not replying to customer reviews or messages
  • Investing or partnering with a wrong marketing agency

Wrapping Up

A solid marketing strategy for food delivery business can help you attract new customers, keep the loyal ones coming back, and stand out in a crowded market. And now you know how to do that perfectly. Remember mistakes will happen but staying consistent in your marketing game would make you stand out from your competitors. 

So, what’s your next move?

FAQ

What is a food marketing strategy?

A food marketing strategy is a plan to promote your food business and attract customers. It includes actions like social media posts, discounts, loyalty programs, and ads to make people aware of your service and encourage them to order.

How do I stand out in a crowded food delivery market?

To stand out, focus on what makes your business unique. Offer something others don’t, like faster delivery, exclusive meals, or personalized deals. Build a strong brand, do app marketing, engage with customers on social media, and ask for reviews to build trust.

How can I increase repeat orders for my delivery business?

To get more repeat orders, reward loyal customers with discounts or free items. Send reminders about your service through push notifications or emails. Make sure your food quality and delivery are consistent so customers want to come back.

Why is my food delivery business not getting enough orders?

You might not be reaching the right people, your prices may be too high, your app or website could be hard to use, or your marketing campaigns or offers aren’t clear. You can start by asking past customers for feedback.

How can I create an effective digital marketing strategy for my food delivery business?

To create an effective digital marketing strategy, focus on understanding your target audience, setting clear marketing goals, utilizing data-driven insights, choosing the right marketing channels, and continuously analyzing and optimizing your campaigns for improved performance.

What are the best marketing channels for promoting a food delivery app?

The best marketing channels for promoting a food delivery app include social media, search engine marketing, email campaigns, and collaborations with influencers and bloggers who resonate with your target audience.

Why is brand awareness important in the food delivery industry?

Brand awareness is crucial in the food delivery industry as it builds customer trust, differentiates your service from competitors, and fosters customer loyalty, ultimately leading to increased sales and a stronger market presence.
